Dance routines, outlandish set designs, wild clothing and one of the best opening sequences in the history of cinema (you can quote me on that!) help make this film a winner.Sure, it won't win any Oscars, but this is one of those films which encompasses more than just humor, but seeks to take it to another level. Technically, the film has very little to offer (with the exception of a few cleverly devised scenes), but the deadpan performances of Myers and Michael Caine and their interaction truly makes for some good comedy. While most of the movie feels like a collection of short vignettes, it does manage to flow succinctly and evenly. Overall, I would see this film multiple times.

Hope you really enjoyed the jokes from the last two movies because here they come again... and again. Fortunately, this one is also bloated with characters and cameos galore which is always a great idea (sarcasm). This movie is such a desperate grab for more money and an attempt to cling to any lingering fondness for the franchise. It's just eye roll inducing nearly the whole way through.

Austin Powers in Goldmember is another great spoof movie for the franchise that while not as as funny as its immediate predecessor, is still great. Mike Myers is once again fantastic in his multiple roles and Beyoncé, Michael Caine, Seth Green and Verne Troyer are all great. It's consistently funny and hilarious at points. Jay Roach's direction is also great, it's extremely well filmed and well paced. The music by George S. Clinton and the soundtrack are good.

In 2002, the Austin Powers series officially ran out of steam with its third installment, GOLDMEMBER. I had enjoyed the series until this point, but it's come to a point where I can't defend it anymore. Everything that was funny about the series has been run into the ground and the third film relies mostly on tired gags and an excessive amount of cameos. I'm not kidding; there are no less than a dozen cameos in this movie. The filmmakers were wise enough to realize that another film with just Austin Powers vs. Dr. Evil wouldn't cut it, so they've branched out to include a new villain (played by none other than Mike Myers, of course). This time around Dr. Evil has teamed up with the "villainous" Goldmember to hold the world ransom once again with a tractor beam. The two plan on using the tractor beam to bring a massive golden asteroid to Earth and colliding it into the North Pole, thereby melting the ice caps and drowning the world's nations. To neutralize Austin Powers, Goldmember has kidnapped Austin's father andwhat elsetaken him back in time to the 1970s to keep him secure. So now it's up to Austin and 70s blaxploitation FBI partner Foxxy Cleopatra to rescue Austin's father and save the world from Dr. Evil's latest scheme.I'm pretty sure Mike Myers and director Jay Roach had just given up at this point. There's nothing in this movie that we haven't seen more than enough in the other films. Shadow gags? Sure. An evil lair with Dr. Evil's face plastered comically on the outside? Absolutely, but this time it's a submarine. Dr. Evil's social ineptitude leading to a hilariously misnamed evil plan? He's labeled his tractor beam project Preparation H. You decide. Musical numbers? Plenty. It's all the same jokes regurgitated in a new setting. Puns, fart jokes, and an abundance of pop culture references. A Japanese businessman named Mr. Roboto? You think they're setting up for a reference to the Styx song---oh, there it is. *cue rim shot* I would've been happier if they could've at least found a way to avoid the over-used time travel plot device. It was the major plot in the first movie as Austin is a 60's swinger displaced in modern times. In the second film, a modernized Austin travels back to the '60s and confronts the lifestyle he left behind. Here, it's not even important to the story. Goldmember transports Austin's father to the '70s, Austin travels back to find him, and five minutes later all of them have returned to modern times. Done. So what was the point of even including a time travel sequence? Because this is Austin Powers, and an Austin Powers movie isn't an Austin Powers movie without time travel. Plus it was the only way to work a 70's blaxploitation character into the plot. Convenient, eh?I don't hate this movie. I was just really disappointed that they couldn't break away from the mold and try to do something fresh to keep the series alive. Everyone just sort of phoned it in here and the franchise has become a joke. How in the world did they ever get Michael Caine to agree to this film? Granted, he's one of the best parts of the movie. Seriously, a lot of people must've owed the filmmakers favors. In the opening alone, we're given Tom Cruise, Gwyneth Paltrow, Kevin Spacey, Danny DeVito, Steven Spielberg, Quincy Jones, and Britney Spears. And this is before the movie even begins. Enough is enough. I really enjoyed the first two Austin Powers films and I would love to see the franchise continue, but only if they're going to try and make it fresh. Drop the old jokes and drop some of the old characters. I think we've had our fill of Fat Bastard andI know I might be alone hereMini-Me. Goldmember's already worn out his welcome as a new character. His entire character is supposed to be funny just because he's Dutch. Seriously, most of his lines are reminders that he's Dutch ("Isn't that veird?"). He's a one-note character. Well, two-note if you account for the fact that he eats his own peeling skin for some reason. That's funny, right? It's time to create some new characters to flesh out the Austin Powers world, even if it's just Myers in a new costume. Don't be afraid to experiment a bit, but please don't crap out another cash-grab as obvious as this one.

Review title: No wonder it's the last one.
Review_body: Hollywood... This is what you get when a popular franchise turns too mainstream. Something impersonal and watered down, where actors of previous movies look like circus monkeys doing what is told of them. And I'm not even sure they had fun doing it. Beyoncé Knowles was an embarrassment, and clearly studios idea to broadcast her « popularity » into the movie. Michael Caine wasn't better either, probably doing this to pay his latest new house... One thing that never change though, are the quality cameos. But even they couldn't redeem everything else...

The action packed opening sequence, filled with cameos from Tom Cruise, Gwyneth Paltrow, Danny Devito, Kevin Spacey, Steven Spielberg and others is simply brilliant, unfortunately it's all a bit downhill from here.With the introduction of Foxey Cleopatra (Beyonce Knowles) a character i simply didn't warm to, Goldmember (Mike Myers) who is not the funniest he's produced, and Nigel Powers (Michael Caine) the best introduction of the three; Austin Powers - Goldmember begins to tire from the moment the opening sequence ends.It's still amusing for Austin Powers fans, but in all honesty i hope its the last movie in the franchise.Watchable, but not as good as the first two films 6/10

Review title: Not As Good As Number 2, But Acceptable
Review_body: I really enjoyed the Austin Powers series. The third one in the installment had a lot of star power, and took place in Hollywood of all places. It builds upon the "movie within a movie" sub genre, and does a fairly good job.The comedic situations are the same, if not better than average. Mike Myers shines as the star, and the cameos are top notch. I recommend it for a lazy afternoon.6 stars

Review title: An improvement on the second film.
Review_body: Austin Powers in Goldmemeber is an improvement on the disappointment that was Austin Powers: The Spy who shagged me. Austin Powers in Goldmemeber isn't in the trilogy curse. I don't think it's the best in the trilogy but it's still better than The Spy who shagged me. The reason why it's better is because it tones it down a little on the immaturity. Am I saying that the film isn't immature? No. I'm just saying that there's not as many gross moments. In the last film, they introduced a new character named Fat Bastard, who is in this film also. But not as much. Fat Bastard is absolutely gross, and one of the reasons why I didn't like it as much. Also, there is a scene where Austin drinks Fat Bastard's crap. And said it's a bit nutty. That's just gross. That was the humor that that film stuck with. i liked it, but it was very gross at times. Austin Powers in Goldmemeber is an improvement for many reasons. It makes you laugh a bit more. The jokes aren't that as crude and I prefer some of the new characters. Or, new character. Michael Caine, the great Michael Caine, plays Austin's father. Just the fact that Michael Caine is in it makes it an improvement. The fact that Scott Evil is turning evil is kind of funny. Austin Powers in Goldmemeber will make you laugh many times. Also, I prefer Beyonce over Heather Grahm. Heather Grahm wasn't bad, but I preferred Elizabeth Hurley and Beyonce. Austin Powers in Goldmemeber isn't a bad third part. It's one of the rare good third part. It's obvious that you should see it. The Plot: In the third part of this famous trilogy, Austin realizes that his father has been kidnapped and is being held in 1979. Dr. Evil and Mini Me are in prison. Austin travels back in time and reunites with his old girlfriend Foxxy, who is working undercover for Goldmemeber in the 70's. Austin and Foxy team up and try to stop Dr. Evil and Goldmember from using Preperation H, which is their new plan for destruction.

Myers goes to the well one more time in the third and one supposes (hopes?) final entry in the Austin Powers saga. The first two were some of the funniest film-making of the last 20 years, the second getting fantastic mileage out of reconditioning much of the schtick from the first. The mojo is pretty much gone by #3, which even the presence of Caine (in the conceptually-inspired role of neglectful dad) can't save. Lack of chemistry between the leads, not enough creative effort, concept worn thin? You got me. Any time one of the primary running jokes centers on a character's large facial mole you know the cupboard has run bare. If there's a fourth movie Myers will play all the roles and the credits will be real short. 6/10 for the (much fewer) gags that work.

Review title: 1. austin powers go with someone your own age. 2. better than SWSM.
Review_body:
Knowles is 21.  Not 31.  Austin powers grow up. Even James Bond doesn't go for the young one's.  (ie watch For Your Eyes Only)Still, this movie is alot better than the spy who shagged me.  We'll just ignore that one.I found Goldmember to be an okay movie with a bad ending.  This was the only thing that really ruined the movie.  Certainly Austin Powers can't go any lower than fat bastard.  But the plot here is simply idiotic.  (as I seem to be facinated with that word in my latest two reviews) I really don't have anything to add to this.  But indeed.  Powers..  Grow up.  Quit dating folks 20 years younger than you.6/10
Quality: 6/10 Entertainment: 5/10 Replayable: 5/10

Review title: Mike Meyers does it again, yeah baby
Review_body: Austin Powers in Goldmember is another great film in the shagadelic series. From the opening spoof AustinPussy one knows it's gonna be a great film. The jokes are on taregt , the script is witty and the cameos are great. Even Beyonce does a good acting job. Very shagdelic.

The third Austin Powers movie, Goldmember, is the last entry in the Austin Powers trilogy (unless the long-talked about fourth film gets out development hell).Basically, the plot is Austin finally beats Dr. Evil and has him put away, but upon being knighted, he sees his father, Nigel Powers, not in attendance. So, he made a deal with Dr. Evil to have the mad scientist transferred to the same prison Mini-Me is in exchange for getting him a criminal mastermind by the name of Goldmember. This takes the secret agent on a time travel trip to 1975, unaware Dr. Evil has plans that require Goldmember to be in the future, one involving a tractor beam and the Midas 22 meteor.Yeah, seeing this movie, it looks like they were beginning to run low on creativity. Mike Myers returns once again to portray Austin Powers and Dr. Evil, as well as new antagonist Goldmember, with Seth Green reprising his role as Scott Evil, and Verne Troyer reprising his role as Mini-Me. New characters include Austin's new sidekick, Foxxy Cleopatra, played by Beyoncé Knowles, and Nigel Powers, played by Michael Caine.Basically, the plot is messy at some points, as it just goes back and forth, and while it does has the same raunchy humor, it seems to have not aged well, and it adds some other unfunny jokes (like Dr. Evil being grossed out by Number Three, played by Fred Savage, because of a mole on his face). However, it still has some good moments (like the beginning dance, there's even the famous Godzilla scene). I have to admit, Dr. Evil's rap in the prison scene was funny, since it made fun of Eminem. It's an okay movie, but it has moments where the trilogy is starting to show its age.

Review title: Gets hilarious towards the end, but overdoses on the crude humor
Review_body:
Now, I must admit the second "Austin Powers" movie did contain a hell of a lot of crude and sexual humor, but it often worked and produced hilarious results.  In other words, it wasn't cheap and pathetic, like many of the gags in this film.The movie starts out with a bang, with many surprise celebrity cameos popping up.  There are other cameos that pop up throughout the course of the film, and I felt they brightened up this otherwise mediocre comedy.
Every other gag in "Goldmember" involves farting, crapping or genitalia. It's a miracle it earned a PG-13.  Other than a hilarious rap duet of "Hard Knocks Life" between Dr. Evil and Mini-Me, in which they wear gold chains and party with half-naked women, the first half is pretty weak.  Most of it is spent trying to tie up loose ends, giving us backstories of Austin and Dr. Evil, even going as far as showing them as roommates back in college. Some of the plot is just plain silly.Every time someone asks me about this movie, the same question comes up: "Can Beyonce act?"  The answer is yes.  She's a fine actress, and I wouldn't be surprised to see her in more and more movies.  Beyonce's acting wasn't the problem; it was the writing.  But to be on the bright side, the film strengthens towards the end with some hilarious bits, including one where Austin stands on Mini-Me's shoulders and they pretend to be one person. He gets summoned to deliver a urine sample.  Funny.  Then him and Mini-Me go behind a screen, and it appears in silhouette like Austin is masturbating. Very funny.  And there's another recycled bit from the second movie, where everyone looks up a spaceship shaped like a pair of boobs.
I liked the first "Austin Powers," I loved the second one, but damn it it's time to retire the franchise.  The first movie set up the joke, the second one played along with it and now the joke is dead and Mike Myers is succumbing to a barrage of cheap toilet humor.  The "Wayne's World" franchise never tired out, because there were only TWO movies.
The character of Goldmember isn't that funny.  His running gag is that he talks funny English (just not funny enough to make me laugh).  He also collects his dead skin and licks it.  Disgusting, definitely.  Funny, far from it.  And I really wish they could've cast someone other than Michael Caine to play Austin's father.  Not that his performance is flawed; it's just I find it almost vomit-inducing to watch an incredible actor making bad penis jokes.Is there gonna be an "Austin Powers 4"?  I hope not.  There are some cases, like in "Lethal Weapon" series, in which a movie is strong enough to spawn a couple of good sequels.  This is not one of those cases.
My score:  6 (out of 10)

Review title: Mr. Powers said it himself - "That is SO not funny."
Review_body: "Austin Powers in Goldmember" starts off with Steven Spielberg directing "Austin Powers in Austinpussy" with Gwyneth Paltrow as Dixie Normous (har de har har) and Tom Cruise, Kevin Spacey, Danny DeVito and another well-known performer - not revealed until near the end - in the roles played by Mike Myers, Mike Myers, Verne Troyer and Mike Myers respectively (oh, all right - Austin Powers, Dr. Evil, Mini-Me and Goldmember). In fact, the movie's insistence on cramming in several cameos in the first ten minutes along with an overelaborate "Soul Bossanova" musical number indicates a motif that runs through the movie - self-indulgence.I purposely avoided "Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me" as part of my refusal to see anything involving the presence of Madonna, but this movie might not have been much worse had she been involved. The storyline of Dr. Evil retrieving Dutch criminal genius Goldmember from the past (why?) and having him kidnap Austin's father Nigel as part of his plan to flood the world just lies there - the problem is that the movie knows it's a rehash and a send-up, and in gleefully playing up its phoniness (not least in Fat Bastard's joke about wire fighting) there's barely a single sincere moment in the entire movie, a fatal mistake given that father-son relationships are a major plot point.The movie's knowledge of its repetitiveness doesn't excuse its laziness either; had the jokes been funny it would have been another matter, but too many are DOA, tasteless or both. Plus it's hard to ignore the suspicion that Myers is enjoying himself a lot more than the audience (what was the point of the "It's The Hard Knocks Life" number with Dr. Evil and Mini-Me?), and Goldmember himself is painful and surplus to requirements. It certainly does well on the eye-candy scale - Britney, Gwyneth, Beyonce Knowles - but other than Seth Green as Scott, the only time the movie genuinely works is when it goes to 1975 all too briefly, featuring the only time Beyonce sings on screen in the movie and the movie's one truly hilarious scene (involving our hero having to talk to her through Nathan Lane). And just when you think it can't get worse, up pop the Osbournes...Since even "1941" was better, it's too bad Spielberg didn't direct for real. (And if I were George S. Clinton - who scored all three movies - I'd not be too pleased at seeing Quincy Jones conduct the scoring orchestra in the opening.)

Review title: Not usually that funny, definitely the weakest of the three
Review_body: I remember the first time I saw this third installment in the Austin Powers franchise. It was New Year's Eve in 2002, and I was sixteen years old. Before then, I had only seen bits of the first two. (I never watch sequels to movies I haven't seen anymore, but sometimes did then.) My first viewing of "Austin Powers in Goldmember" was definitely a good one, so I watched the first two within the next few weeks after that, in reverse order. For a while, I was a big fan of the franchise, but watching the entire trilogy again in recent years, I have discovered that I now think the first one, "Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery", is the best, and the two sequels (1999's "Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me" and then this one), each brought the franchise down a step.As usual, Dr. Evil has another plan for world domination, but soon after he announces it to his colleagues, Austin Powers comes to arrest him! However, the British secret agent is soon informed that his father, Nigel, has been kidnapped, so he goes to talk to his foe in prison! He learns that a Dutch man from the 1970's known as "Goldmember" was involved in this abduction, so he travels back to 1975! At Goldmember's club, Powers meets Foxxy Cleopatra, an FBI agent working undercover. They witness Nigel Powers captured and taken through a time machine to 2002, so Austin then takes Foxxy back to 2002 with him. Dr. Evil and Mini-Me soon escape from their maximum security prison, and join Goldmember in a dastardly plot to cause a global flood! Obviously, it's up to Austin Powers and his new sidekick to try and stop them! Mike Myers played two roles in the first film (Austin Powers and Dr. Evil), and added a third alter ego (Fat B%$#&*%) in the second, so it's no surprise that he plays a fourth one in this third installment, Goldmember. I no longer care much for Fat B%$#&*%, which includes his appearance in this film, with scenes involving more toilet humour, and jokes about his sumo wrestling diaper, but Goldmember might be worse. I don't think I was ever a huge fan of his, but used to find him more acceptable. His exaggerated Dutch accent is supposed to be funny, but it's actually perhaps a little irritating. The film isn't completely straight-faced, it has its moments, such as Austin Powers unable to keep quiet about the mole on Number Three's face, and another crude shadow gag (like the one in "The Spy Who Shagged Me"). However, the laughs in this film are still smaller in number than they are in its two predecessors, and it may get even more juvenile here than before. In the role of Austin Powers' sidekick, Beyoncé Knowles puts on a better performance than Heather Graham did in the first sequel, but that doesn't make this film superior."Goldmember" is obviously partially a spoof of "Goldfinger", the 1964 adaptation of the James Bond novel of the same name. Unfortunately, this third Austin Powers installment is far inferior to that third James Bond flick from 38 years earlier. On the other hand, "Austin Powers in Goldmember" is definitely better than "Die Another Day", the Bond film which came out the same year. If you ask me, that film, the twentieth installment in the franchise, and Pierce Brosnan's last outing as Bond of four, is undoubtedly the worst Bond flick to date! Nonetheless, this second sequel to Mike Myers' James Bond spoof showed that the series may be wearing thin, and although it's been nearly seven years since it came into theatres, it looks like a fourth Austin Powers movie has been confirmed. I'm not going to ignore it when it comes out, but since each of the two sequels brought the franchise down a step, it wouldn't surprise me if Austin Powers 4 brings it down yet another step, then it would follow the pattern.

My Take: The most elaborate and probably the funniest of the three.After the success of the first two AUSTIN POWERS movies, a sequel had to come out for the sake of the cash. And while it's meant to get a lot more money, AUSTIN POWERS: GOLDMEMBER, the third of the spy-spoof series, is still very funny, and you have to admit, Mike Myers still has the 'Powers'! Adding to his characters of Austin Powers, Dr. Evil and Fat Bastard, Myers also plays the new "villain", Mr. Goldmember, a parody of the famous James Bond villain Auric Goldfinger. The film, itself, is still a parody of all the classic James bond movies and many other movies. But, thanks to the creativity that's still intact upon the screenwriters, GOLDMEMBER still has enough funny bits to delight fans and other viewers that pass by alike. It may just be the the most elaborate AUSTIN POWERS yet.However, since it is done twice before, some things get pretty tired. It may be the most elaborate of the three, but the material certainly hasn't changed. Austin is still the same character he was in the first two films. Still has a thing for his fellow agents, always women, and he still has bad teeth, of course. Dr. Evil still wants to rule the world, and still coping with his relationship with his son (this time has improved, though). New characters include sassy "sugar" spy Foxxy Cleopatra (Beyonce Knowles), a parody of female blaxploitation spy characters like COFFY played by Pam Grier, as well as Austin Powers father ("His Fasha!" says Goldmember in a Dutch-accent), played by Michael Caine, accompanied by the Mini Cooper he used in the role he played in the original THE Italian JOB.Director Jay Roach is still having fun with the material, and we have the same amount of fun he had. The comedy bits, although some repetitive, are still uproariously funny. The cameos of Tom Cruise, Gwyneth Paltrow, Danny DeVito, Kevin Spacey and director Steven Spielberg in a pseudo-M:I:2 opening credits of "a new Austin Powers" film called "Austinpussy" (a nod to Bond's OCTOPUSSY, which also rumored to be the film's working title) surprisingly funny, as i the long-running joke about the "Mole" (in a literal sense of the word). It's probably the funniest of the three so far. Go see it! Rating: **** out of 5.

Review title: Is it as good as the last one? NO BABY!
Review_body: Austin Powers Goldmember has all the hallmarks of the first two film. It looks great ,it is funny and it has no story worth speaking about.This is better than the first but does not quite live up to the second. The problem being the story is very week but what it lacks in a story it makes up for with gimmicks , none more so than the first 10 minutes when we see an array of stars making the Austin Powers film which is directed by Stephen Spielberg. Now thats a film i would love to see!! There are some very funny moments such as the time Austin is behind a screen and gives birth to Mini Me and the camio appearance of the Osbournes. When Mike Myers makes Austin Powers 4 i just hope he spends a little more time on the story. 7 out of 10.

Review title: A Weak Entry in the Series
Review_body:
The third Austin Powers movie offers the viewer little in originality. The few characterizations that work in "Goldmember" are not original and worked much better in the first two Austin Powers movies. The material that is new to "Goldmember" contributes little; it provides the weakest links in a weak movie.  Another criticism is that the comedy is significantly more crass and vulgar than in the first two. Where the predecessors had had some wit and style, "Goldmember" tends to rely on tired potty humor.
Unless you are a die-hard Powers fan and must see them all, skip it.

Jay Roach's "Austin Powers in Goldmember" is just plain funny. Mike Meyers is back and smashing as Austin Powers in this sequel. Meyers also wrote "Goldmember", and you've got to acknowledge him for rifling out the jokes. Not all of them work, and you really have to credit the misfires. The first 10 minutes of the movie which includes classic cameos from Tom Cruise (who is really great), Gwenyth Paltrow, and Britney Spears, is some of the funniest and off-the-wall movie-making ever.Dr. Evil (Meyers too) is back, and again threatening world destruction, though I can't remember exactly what for. I saw the movie a couple weeks ago. Austin must again go back in time, though this time to the mid-70's very cool disco era, to track down the Dutch villain, Goldmember (also Meyers). Along the way, he renews a relationship with an old partner Foxxy Cleopatra (Beyounce Knowles). One of the curious things is that Meyers keeps making unfunny Dutch jokes which goes on throughout the movie, and in doing so is hilarious. We also learn that Austin has an incomplete relationship with his father Nigel Power (perfectly played by Michael Caine). It is something that has cost him in the present. Will Austin complete this relationship with his father? Well, it is almost moving, touching, and inspiring. Almost.The actual story is secondary, and Meyer's script is like a bizarre stream of consciousness. Other highlights include a laugh until you can't breath Jay-Z rap parody by Dr. Evil and Mini-Me (Verne Troyer) in prison, and the scenes of Young Austin and Young Evil in prep school which is kind of a weird "Smallville" satire.One of the surprises is that the new villain, Goldmember, is not a big deal. Yeah, baby. Though Austin, Dr. Evil, Fat Bastard, Nigel Powers, and Foxxy Cleopatra are very good. Special props to Tom Cruise. "Goldmember" is not the greatest movie, but it is one of the funniest. Whatever you do, don't miss the beginning of the movie.

Goldmember is really much better than the first Austin Powers sequel, entitled The Spy who shagged me. Although there are some similar jokes, this one gets off much better. It seems that there are some standard sort of jokes, sequences or quotes that have been used in previous Austin Powers movies and will be used again in upcoming Austin Powers movies. Things like 'the laugh' by Dr.Evil and his crew, the 'shush thing' between Dr.Evil and his son Scotty or Austin's rambling when he finds something so amusing he must tell three jokes about it. All of this is very much like the standard lines and or fragments there are in James Bond films. The typical: 'Bond, James Bond' or the exploding stuff in Q's lab or even the Miss Moneypenny dialogues. Nonetheless, this film is enjoyable and exciting, more then it's predecessor and even a bit more than the original. The cause for that, is that there are more jokes that will make you laugh like an idiot (because the joke is idiotic) and because the actors are much better than in The spy who shagged me. Contrary to that film and very much in line with International man of Mystery, the casting has chosen for quality actors and actresses. There is no young number two and no Felicity Shagwell, who were not good and pretty but shallow respectively. Rather we have Foxxy Cleopatra and Nigel Powers. Beyoncé Knowles from Destiny's Child (Foxxy) succeeds in being Foxxy and in portraying a good and likeable character, whereas Michael Caine (Nigel Powers) also succeeds in portraying a good daddy Powers. Verne Troyer (Mini-Me) is even better than he was in The spy who shagged me. He was good before, but he is just hilarious this time around. Mike Myers (Austin/Goldmember/Fat Bastard/Dr.Evil) is as good as ever. I mean he is just great, making silly faces and putting on foreign accents. In spite of the returning characters and the new ones, there are quite a few celebrity cameo's, none of which were annoying by the way. If that alone is not reason enough to watch this film, I don't know what is. If even Britney Spears, the queen of actresses (smirk), does not succeed in f..king up this film , nobody will!!! I mean she is not too bad on the eye, but acting is nothing for her. That girl (woman maybe) can't so much as sing a note properly (unlike miss Knowles), so how can one expect her to act even average. She cannot even perform average in her own profession (or is her profession not singing, but rather walking around with very few, tight clothes???). In addition to the very good acting (this is a spoof you know!), there is lots of variation, for there are moments of pity, moments of wonder, moments of stupidity and a many moments of laughter. I can't wait for the fourth in the series (I know there will be one), but what will it be called?
7,5 out of 10

Review title: "They're using the same !@$$!@$ jokes that they did in the last Austin Powers movie!"
Review_body: Having the characters in the film acknowledge that the format is stale does not disguise the fact, even if it's Ozzy Osbourne.While I rated both a five, this is a marginal further drop from The Spy Who Shagged Me, a further increase into its own sense of self and reheated jokes. I said when reviewing the original, and best, film that I couldn't decide who was funniest out of the two lead characters. This is virtually nul and void here, as while Austin still raises a smile, all the scenes with Doctor Evil are laboured, flat and badly paced. A new addition to Myers's cast of characters - the absurdly unfunny title character Goldmember - adds little to proceedings. An apart script editing blip even sees them use the humorous "smelting accident" gag a second time.Beyonce and Michael Caine add some spice to the film and there's a fun cameo role from Heroes's Masi Oka, but this is a franchise running on empty and really just stuck on repeat. Quite improbably, a fourth film is listed as being in production for 2009. Maybe the subsequent seven year lay off will have reheated Myers's muse... though judging by "The Love Guru", probably not.

Goldmember is pure shagadelic fun from beginning to end, fueled by the manic and inspired energy of Mike Myers - fearless, boundless and extremely childish (his best quality).  I liked it better than the first two Austin Powers films combined.  And Beyonce Knowles is extremely easy on the eyes (although she may be hard on other parts - use your imagination).  Lots of surprises here, including an insanely inspired opening sequence, great plot twists and an ending that leaves you positively drooling for the next installment.  So what are you sittin' there for?!   Get off the couch and go see it NOW, you fat bastard.

Review title: Not as funny as part 2, but on equal footing as part 1.
Review_body: Austin Powers in Goldmember is a very funny film, just as funny as the first Austin Powers, but unfortunately nowhere near the the second film, which I consider the best of the series. In fact, it's obvious the series is losing its steam, with jokes from the first films being only repeated over and over again (in essence, beating a dead horse). Even Mike Myers as Austin Powers/Dr. Evil seems to be growing tired of this role - and though his Fat Bastard role was funny, his new Goldmember role wasn't anything new. The only exception to an otherwise repetitious roles for most of the cast, I thought Verne Troyer was again hilarious as Mini Me. A funny 7 out of 10.

Review title: Please stop right there Mr. Director
Review_body: This movie is completely witless. It's painful to watch. I admit I liked the two first movies in this series, but this one is too much. Yes, there's a few laughs, but too little too late. I'm just getting tired of Mike Myers' antics. And the Foxxy Cleopatra character wasn't funny, too bad for Beyonce Knowles. As for the Mini-Me, please get rid of him, he's just so annoying. Let's just hope we'll not be "shagging" a fourth time soon. Didn't we have enough already of those scatological tasteless jokes?Out of 100, I gave it 62. That's good for *½ out of ****.Seen in Sudbury, on January 1st, 2003 (what a way to star the year!).

Review title: Lame recap of previous efforts with a bigger budget but ever cheaper gags.
Review_body: Here we go again in a series that is not so much a spoof, as a spoof on a spoof. The original Austin Powers was more a spoof on In Like Flint (with James Coburn), Jason King and the other swinging sixties anything-goes James Bond rip-offs than the real 007 movies.The franchise isn't really a series of films as such, but a chance to showcase Mike Myers talents in a series of guises including, for the first time, a mad penis painting Dutchman - Goldmember - who strangely doesn't even know his own language from German!(Maybe that was a deliberate mistake - who knows and frankly who cares?!)A success has many fathers, but failure is an orphan. Good to see that now we are on a winner we have star day players onboard to remind us that they too wouldn't mind a hit franchise (or two) of their own.The greatest thing about the script is that the target audience hasn't seen the original thing and there are still loads of old Benny Hill sight gags to steal.(You've been caught baby, yeah....)Every time the writers (which includes Myers) goes back to the series they merely add to what they have created before without discarding much. Michael Caine is added as Power's (mostly absent) father and Beyonce plays a foxy blacksploitation sidekick (very well acted too - bang on the money!), but we have nothing really that new on the menu. The rule of thumb being that as the  gags get cheaper the sets get more expensive.No film has to be anything but a time passer, but what is evident here is that when you take away any element of danger or intrigue you have nothing to cling on to, even silly comedy needs a forward plot device.All-in-all a product  that is more interesting off-screen that it is on. A money making machine that doesn't want to stop because behind the face-pulling and the look-at-us-we-can laugh-at-ourselves we have a serious business. This won't be last of the series because we have money being made and while money is being made no Hollywood franchise will be dropped. The only alternative is that Myers gets tired of getting tens of millions for his so-so performances. Who knows - maybe he has hidden ethics? Let us hope so.

Review title: Here we go again, and hopefully for the last time. More unfunny racial stereotypes and toilet humour.
Review_body: Totally weak, unfunny and disgusting Austin sequel made me realize i actually detested the series.It relies on racial stereotyping and hatred. Every character is a racial stereotype:Austin = BritishMustafa = Middle EastFoxxy Cleopatra = African Americans, referencing blaxploitation chick Cleopatra JonesFat Bastard = Scottish, as well as over-weight people - how matureFrau Farbissina = GermansFook Yu = Nondescript AsiansAs well as many other minor characters - but the strangest, most disgusting blow of all was Goldmember himself: a rollerskating, be-freckled (like a disease covering his skin), orange haired, leotard-wearing man who picks scabs (or dry skin or something) off his body and eats it. He's supposed to be, what was it, Swedish, danish? Which random culture shall we pick to make a joke of?So racial misunderstandings do not equal comedy.But the greatest thing wrong with the third Austin Powers, is its just more of the same. Same dorky unfunny jokes which don't work as spoof because nobody has seen the original spy movies they were originally supposed to be taking off.3/10. For the opening sequence of the faux movie with star cameos. Otherwise, monotonous, repetitive and ridiculous stereotyping "comedy." Plus, Beyonce can not act.
Cheap dirty comedy that parodies spy films of the era that holds up pretty well. Damn quotable too.4/5.

Other than the cameos, the hilarious character of Goldmember (Myers does his faux Dutch accent so well), and the very rare other joke that worked, I was bored by this largely recycled toilet humor retread. As for this installment's female co-star, Beyoncé is no Elizabeth Hurley or even Heather Graham. Not a worthwhile viewing experience, 6/10.

Review title: Have we come to the end of the road?
Review_body: Not as enjoyable as the first 2 films, but good all the same.  I'm wondering if some of the in jokes of Austin Powers are coming to a natural end -- which I'm wondering if Myers has spotted himself given that the script is often self mocking of the concept as a whole.There were some excellent laughs in this ... "I thought I smelled cabbage!", and Michael Caine added a lot to the story in the kind of role that he alone can excel in.The number of characters that Myers is playing himself is starting to take some shine off Powers & Dr Evil, and the character of Goldmember is not particularly funny -- with Fat Bastard going nowhere as a character also.All this aside, if you go expecting to see a typical Mike Myers film, you'll enjoy this.

Once again the best part is everything up to and including the intro song. The disappearance of Heather Graham is ignored all together. Goldmember kicks Foxy Cleopatra over the shoulder four times, time 2 or 3 she dodges once, then gets hit. Maybe I am riding a high form having just seen it, but this is the best of the Austin Powers movies. The creators seems to be able to expand what worked in the past movies. What makes all the cameos great is that you are not waiting for them as they are not given away in the trailers. A cool movie.

I think it's safe to say that if you liked "Austin Powers International Man of Mystery" and "Austin Powers The Spy Who Shagged Me" then you'll probably enjoy this film as well.  I'd have to say that I liked this film just as much as the other two films.The story is pretty much what you'd expect, and pretty similar to the first two films, but that is to be expected.  There is a lot of regurgitated comedy from the first two films, but at the same time there is a lot of original comedy that just had me busting up.The cast is fantastic, Mike Myers is a comedic genius!!!  And Jay Roach is a superb director!  There are some films that you just don't want another director to touch, and I think this is one of those films.  Michael Caine, Seth Green, Beyonce Knowles, Robert Wagner and Verne Troyer are just great in this film!  I think it's great that Michael Caine agreed to do this film, and quite appropriate in that Mike Myers parodies some of Michael Caine's past films.  I definitely have respect for actors that do diverse roles. There are quite a few cameo appearances in this film, but I won't mention any of them as not to ruin the surprise for you (although, if you're reading the review on this site you probably already know about them).I thought "Austin Powers in Goldmember" was a great addition to the Austin Powers franchise.  I'm not really sure how they would do a 4th installment, but you never know.  I hope you enjoy the film as much as I do.  Thanks for reading,-Chris

Review title: Extremely hilarious with so much laughs
Review_body: Austin Powers in Goldmember is another comical genius film I guess. Maybe not better than the 1st film but it is very close. Dr. Evil again is tremendously hilarious like he has been in the past Austin Powers film. I don't really like when Dr. Evil becomes good because I have always liked him better as the bad guy but he is still hilarious. Scott was even funny in this, like when he was running away in that weird kind of run. That was hilarious!! Oh and can you believe it, Mini Me was really funny too because I really didn't like him in the second film that much. Pretty much all the parts in the film were hilarious like when Austin and Dr. Evil are younger and numerous of other extremely funny scenes. Highly recommend.9/10

Mike Myers returns for the third installment of his "Austin Powers" franchise.  In "Goldmember," he comes full circle with the histories of Austin and Dr. Evil.  Myers again plays shagadelic secret agent Austin Powers, his arch-nemesis Dr. Evil and horrible henchman Fat Bastard, and now also a new bad guy, the Dutch hedonist Goldmember.  I found this movie hilarious and outrageous!  It had a lot of crude humor, like Austin hiding behind Mr. Roboto's fountain.  But there was also a good amount of self-parody.  The best scenes included Dr. Evil's prison rap video, and the suggestive subtitles in Mr. Roboto's office.  The several cameos were also enjoyable, especially Ozzy Osbourne pointing out the joke carried over from "The Spy Who Shagged Me."  The scene with Godzilla and its copyright was a relevant joke, considering the MPAA's temporary ban on the use of the title "Goldmember."  I did have a complaint about the continuity.  The difference in Austin Powers' trademark "choppers" was noticeable.  And although I'd have liked an explanation for the absence of Felicity Shagwell, I'm glad she was not revealed in the movie as a fembot!  Anyway, with this third installment, Austin Powers goes out with a bang!

Review title: Austin Powers in 2002 goes back to the 1970's, bummer!
Review_body: I'm a fan of the first two Austin Powers films where after the first movie became a somewhat cult classic, a sequel (The Spy Who Shagged Me) followed where it proved to be even greater laughs than the first movie. The first two movies were shot in the nineties, yet with Goldmember being shot in the beginning of the 2000's, it felt wasted to see another Austin Powers movie when other comedy flicks followed.The plot of Austin Powers 3 has the famous British super agent going back in time. This time around it's the 1970's where he must rescued his father Nigel, played by Michael Caine, who never really was around for Austin, when a villain by the name of Goldmember (Mike Myers in a fourth role with Dr. Evil being the second role and Fat B as the third), a Dutchman who has the ability to turn anything into gold including a man's twigs and berries. Austin gets help from a soul singer by the name of Foxy Cleopatra (Beyonce Knowles) along with getting help from convict Dr. Evil, but not before escaping with plans of his own.There are other characters that come back from the film from Fat Bastard (or Fat B. to the offensive people), Mini-Me, Number Two, Scott Evil and more where the real moments of the film just like the first two movies are the spoofs from spy movies to recent pop culture (Britney Spears, music videos, dance sequences and more) bringing out the true guns of comedy. There's even cameo appearances by major media influences from Tom Cruise, Gwyneth Paltrow, Steven Spielberg, Katie Couric, Quincy Jones, Masi Oki (before the Heroes fame) and more where it doesn't mean the better.I love Beyonce, but I didn't think she was the right choice to play Austin Powers' love interest where there wasn't any connection between them during their scenes together.Austin Powers was welcomed in the 1990's, but I'm not sure if the new century is ready for him.

A sporadicaly funny sequel that I actualy enjoyed a bit more than the previous chapter ("Spy Who Shagged Me") which I thought was dull. This one has Austin (once more played by Mike Myers) teaming with his dad (an amusing Michael Caine) to foil another plot by Dr. Evil. Some amusing cameo appearances and a hillarious turn by the talented Seth Green (who was all but ignored in the two previous chapters) make most of this watchable. Though the bodily function jokes and Myers mugging at the camera do get tiresome. GRADE: B-
Just love this, soooo many quotes.. It's silly but good fun.

Review title: Could be the funniest in the trilogy !
Review_body: Part one I didn't thought was very funny, but then part two was much better. And this one is might the funniest. It has a lot of funny jokes still some of the jokes are not a bit funny(but in these kinds of films, there are always like that). The beginning is hilarious and also the "hard knock life" song is very funny. Mike Myers is a talented comedian and oh of course you should watch it because of Beyoncé also! 7/10

Well, well...here is the kind of movie in where thinking is forbidding as this is fun and nothing but fun! All the usual characters are back (apart from Beyonce Knowles who plays a brilliant discodiva-gunqueen like we know from times in where Shaft ruled the white screen) as Austin goes back in the 70's in where he has to catch a vilain called Goldmember (hence the James Bondmovie "Goldfinger") and of course the superb Dr. Evil and his comrade-son Mini-Me. The movie is an amazing collection of jokes (two Japanese twinsisters who are called Fook Mi and Fook Yu, can it be better???) and parody on movies like "Mission Impossible", "The Italian Job" and tons of other things. That's the way haha I like it....

There are 4 good laughs in this movie. I am amazed that people consider this humor. It was so boring for 95% of the movie that I was very disappointed I spent $3.95 to see it on cable.Don't see this movie until it comes out on commercial TV so they can edit out the 4 laughs with the commercials and then you'll see how completely pathetic and stupid this movie is (and humor in general these days).nice soundtrack... then again if you had infinite resources to pick - this would be the easy part. 5/10... I should have voted 1/10.ZafoidPS: So-called "stupid" movies (movies made with the *intention* of appearing stupid) are MUCH funnier than this mistake.Z

Okay, I suppose "Goldmember" is fun enough.  I loved the first "Austin Powers" movie, and was disappointed by the second one.  So, expecting very little here, I enjoyed this one fine.  The thing is, like the "Naked Gun" series, when you watch all three movies, they kind of run together.  I like both series, but what I mean is that there's not much to differentiate this entry from it's predecessors.  Non-tall people are given a more favorable light... almost, and Scott Evil -my favorite character- hardly does anything this time out.  Anyway, this is a perfectly good "let's bring the whole gang to the dollar theater" movie.Now, let's talk about that "Two Towers" trailer...

Review title: A funny movie, but the weakest of the three.
Review_body: ** 1/2Starring: Mike Myers, Beyonce Knowles, Michael Caine, and Verne Troyer.The follow-up to the hilarious Austin Powers franchise started in a hilarious opening.  Things were looking quite up from there, except that it fell down a deep hill as the movie went on.  The movie's plot is practically like the first two movie's plots.  Austin having fun, he time travels, finds Dr. Evil, bathroom jokes, and so on.  Austin Powers goes back to 1975 to find his kidnapped father.  He meets up with Foxxy Cleopatra, a cross between pam Grier and Tamara Dobson. I really didn't like her character too much.  She was funny at times, but she really was there for eye candy. Austin and Foxxy find a new foe, Goldmember.  A strange Dutch who isn't that funny and makes you cringe more than laugh.  They save Austin's father and must foil Dr. Evil and Goldmember's plan.  This movie is full of bathroom humor, sometimes funny, sometimes stupid.  They had some really good moments but not enough.  I must also say that Fat Bastard was hardly in this, yet he stole every scene he was in.  Dr. Evil and Minime also steal every scene they are in.

Review title: The funniest movie in the Austin Powers movies!
Review_body: Starring: Mike Myers, Seth Green, Michael Caine and Beyonce KnowlesGuest Appearances by: Tom Cruise, Britney Spears, John Travolta, Kevin Spacey, Danny DeVito, Gwyneth Paltrow, The Osburnes and Nathan LaneGenre: ComedyRated PG-13This is the third adventure of Austin Powers! In this third installment of the Austin Powers trilogy, Austin Powers' (Mike Myers) father, Nigel Powers (Michael Caine) has been kidnapped by Goldmember (Mike Myers)! So then Austin goes to get information from Dr. Evil (Mike Myers) on where to found Goldmember and that was 1975. As Austin chases Dr. Evil, Mini-Me and Goldmember through time, he stops in 1975 to "connect" with an old girlfriend, detective Foxy Cleopatra (Beyonce Knowles), and requests her help to track the villains and save his father. In this movie Scott (Seth Green) finally decides to become evil and follow his father's foot steps! Dr. Evil's plan in this movie is that he is going to have a meteor hit the Earth by pulling it down with a magnetic laser. The funniest part in this movie is when we see Fat Bastard (Mike Myers) in a sumo-wrestling contest in Tokyo. Another funny part is when Austin and Foxy are at this place in Tokyo they were trying to talk to this guy and he is speaking in Japanese and some stuff keeps blocking the subtitles and it makes him look like he is saying nasty things! They were lots of other parts I liked! Another thing is that in this movie is that Dr. Evil finally gets what he had wanted which was sharks with laser beams attached to their heads. There has got to be 4th Austin Powers movie!

This is in many ways routine - well-made, with a good joke/time ratio, lots of the required silliness, and even a few moments of inspiration. Some new contributions to the series work better than others (Nigel Powers: good, Goldmember: bad), but by going through such a checklist one by one I make the same mistake the writers made: not thinking about the picture as a whole.As a whole, the film is too disjointed. There are good little tidbits here and there, mostly at the required hilarity level, but the joints squeak and squeal.  That is particularly noticeable towards the beginning when we get a few musical numbers too many.  Apart from this Burlesque-inspired combination of music and comedy, the disjointness can be blamed on several underdevelopments of plot and characters. The time travel to 1975 was confined to a few references of 1970s culture, the Goldmember character is largely side-lined, and Mini-me's defection deserved more attention.In the end, it's the Blazing Saddles school of comedy, not the more coherent approach of Support Your Local Sheriff.

Review title: Few laughs.. in a word.. wait for the rental
Review_body: While there are some good laughs, there are far to few of them and it makes for some dull watching out for the entire film.  The new character "Goldmember" that Mike Meyers has created is pretty lame.  In the end there are some new things that work out, but there's also some dumb repetitve gags that you have either seen in previous Austin films, or old horrific SNL sketches.In a word, I wouldn't pay for this in the theatre If I knew this is what I was going to see, I'd probably be satisfied with a cheap rental though, and I suggest you wait and do the same.I went in wanting to let loose and just have a lot of laughs, but I can honestly say I didn't get my money's worth.Rating 5 out of 10

The first seven minutes--a parody of `Mission: Impossible II'--is chock full of celebrities. After that, there's virtually no reason to keep watching--it's another `Saturday Night Live' sketch that goes on far too long. Mike Myers' indulgences remain as unchecked as ever which means that skits he thinks are funny, regardless of what anyone else might think, are included in all their humorless glory. Myers is probably the only comedian in movies today who doesn't seem to have the slightest notion about timing--all he wants to do is focus on scatological and homo jokes--and how he can be proud to deliver a comedy with so much dead air is beyond the ken of this reviewer. There are only two good lines and they are `Preparation H feels good on the whole' and `You're a cunning linguist and I am a master debater!' Now you don't have to watch.

Goldmember completes the Austin Powers franchise with little more than a nod to the 1st and 2nd films. The story's recycled again, Dr. Evil (Myers) insists on world domination, Austin Powers (Myers) awkwardly saves the day. It's not rocket science. Myers is up to his usual tricks; Evil garners the most laughs and Powers is, well, Powers. Mini Me gets the discriminated, but they're still just as funny. The 3rd installment sees two new inclusions, Beyonce Knowles's Bond-esque girl Foxxy Cleopatra, who lacks the emotional pull that Heather Graham had, and Michael Caine as Austin Powers' father, Nigel Powers, who fits his role suitably. Myers' Goldmember and the returning Fat Bastard fair less better. Still, Myers carries on doing what he does best, and that's making (most) viewers laugh.Check out my other reviews on http://straighttelling.co.uk

"Goldmember" was funny in parts and was mostly entertaining throughout. Mike Myers was very good and so was Beyoncé Knowles.  The story was a parody of many old spy movies and 1960's action movies.  Unfortunately the tone of the movie seems to be more and more scatological.  I find that humor rather juvenile and to be a product of poor writing and a lack of inspiration. Maybe they are trying to attract a certain younger cruder audience but it would seem they are alienating a large portion of market.  I'm not looking forward to the next episode since the jokes lost their interest when I graduated from grammar school.   See it for the parody and Mike Myers but be forewarned much of the movie is crude.

I might be in the minority but out of the 2 sequels this was my favourite and I got tons of laughs thanks to the brilliant characters that Mike Myers created and the support from Verne Troyer (Mini Me), Beyonce (Foxy), Michael Caine (Nigel) and Seth Green (Scott) and all the other regulars. Unlike the previous version it didnt spoof far from the subject but went in a strange direction. 18 years have passed so the ship has sailed on any future sequels but it was a brilliant trilogy all the same

Review title: flawed but good installment to the A.P. saga
Review_body: i wasnt expecting much out of goldmember. having read many bad reviews i thought i would be in the majority. international man of mystery was definetly the best A.P. movie. the spy who shagged me wasn't as good. fat bastard and mini me were unwelcome,heather graham was terrible and they wrote off IMOM by turning vanessa into a fembot. but goldmember was better than TSWSM. although some jokes were rehashed and the cast was way too large, it still made me laugh. goldmember was a terrible idea and wasn't funny. michael caine did a good job as nigel powers. beyonce knowles was surprisingly good as foxxy cleopatra, but still no liz hurley. fat bastard and mimi me were a little better this time round. and still great performances from seth green, mindy sterling and robert wagner. the cameos at the start were definitely the films laughing point. number 3 was the best and most welcome  new character, although the films soundtrack was awful. overall, very entertaining. 7 out of 10

Review title: The funniest of all three Austin Powers movies
Review_body: I thought the first two films were hilarious, but this has got to be the best. When I saw this at the cinema four years ago, I was surprised to see the Austinpussy film-within-a-film but I soon realised it was part of the actual film itself.Beyonce makes a great sidekick for Austin and she is especially helpful in the scene in Mr Roboto's Headquarters where the subtitles look dogdy (for example, "Please eat some s**t," becomes, "Please eat some shitake mushrooms.). One of the best puns in this film is the name of Gwyneth Paltrow's character, which is Dixie Normous. My dad found that name terrible yet funny. I also liked the scene where the Japanese twins ask for Austin's autograph and they tell him their names are Fook Yu and Fook Mi, which is similar to the Dixie Normous joke, but they sound a lot ruder because they sound like the F-word.People who already like the first two films may like this as well because it's just plain hilarious. 9/10.

Review title: Hilarious, but the weak link in the trilogy
Review_body: (There could possibly be spoilers, so read at your own risk.  And if they are spoilers, they're not big)This movie was hilarious, no doubt saying that.  But it is definitely the worst of the three.  It's not as fresh as the first, or as original of jokes as the second, but it still has its great moments (The cameos were hysterical).  Although some cameos didn't deliver anything but stupidity. Can somebody answer me, what the hell was Britney Spears and the Osbournes doing there?!?  I didn't hear a single laugh out of anyone in the audience when those two cameos arrived.  Here are my pros and cons of the movie:Pros: 1.  Once again, the hilarious cameos.  I will only say that Danny DeVito's was hysterical. 2.  Fat Bastard (who, surprisingly, isn't there long enough)Minime, and Dr. Evil steal every scene they are in.Cons: 1.  Once again, the useless cameos. 2.  Goldmember, was not funny whatsoever besides his strange dutch accent. He was there to gross you out with his skin problem. 3.  Foxxy Cleopatra was unfunny also and is just there to wear cleavage (I didn't mind but she was the worst girl of the three).  4.  Ridiculous and sometimes, just stupid, bathroom jokes.  5.  They steal many of the past two movies jokes and put them in this one, which was aggravating.6.  The absence of Heather Graham's character wasn't a good thing.  7.  Michael Caine's character was a little bit aggravating but had many funny jokes.  8.  Last but not least, the worthless ending.  I was so anticipating the ending to see what happens, but it ends up stupid.So as you can see there are many more cons than pros but I will still recommend you to see it, but only if you like bathroom jokes, which I don't. Rating 7 out of 10.

Review title: Good, but not the best of the bunch
Review_body: Granted the opening is the best of the trilogy, but then it doesn't hold up to the first two. I never found the character of Goldmember funny. He's just a weird guy who makes a movie or disco reference and then says the name of what he is referencing. And this is also the decade where penis jokes were wearing thin. It was funny in the 70's and 80's, the 90's they got tiresome, in the 2000's it's like "Okay, enough." The joke where Fat Bastard talks about his terrible problem with obesity, sad music plays and then he farts worked in the second film, but in this movie, we saw it coming. Then he describes what the fart smells like. That's not funny.Yeah, there's many moments where it just Mike ad-libbing and it gets put in the movie. The filmmakers may have found it funny, but the audience doesn't. It's times where it's like the filmmakers only care about what they want, instead of the audience. Which what you're supposed to be doing if you're a filmmaker.The object in space that looks like a private part was funny in the second film but here, not so much. And the joke about the mole is just not funny.However, the movie is fun and fast paced, the score was great and it was just epic. I like it when silly comedies get epic. The joke about the subtitles was hysterical, the scene where Austin and Mini-me are behind the screen was hysterical, Beyonce was really good as Foxxy and yes I was surprised at the twist at the end. I went to see this film twice. The second time, I saw it with my friend and his jaw dropped opened at that scene.Is it the best of the three? No, I think the second film is the funniest. It is hugely enjoyable, but far from Groovy.

Review title: one of the greatest film openings ever filmed
Review_body: Ok so, AP3 is not really a great film; i wouldn't put it in the same category as Blade Runner, or Dune, or Oh Brother.What it does have, however, is one of the greatest introductory scenes ever put to film.AP3's extended opening credits, with the fake film, and the dance act, leading into the first scene, is absolutely a masterpiece and worthy enough to be watched on its own.The rest of the film is ok-ish. It has to be said that the Austin Powers series is fairly unique in having each of the three films be *better* than the preceding one. But, it's still your standard spy-film spoof, and the whole thing gets a bit tedious in the end. Because, strangely, it doesn't need any of that. The various cameos and interludes are great on their own -Evil Scott, the Belgians, speaking English English, all great skits, i guess you do need a framework to put them in, so comedy-James-Bond is has to be.Anyway, decent film with some very unique touches. My vote: 8/10 (7/10 for the main story)

Review title: Beyonce' Knowles Made This Movie What It Is!
Review_body: This movie was so funny! Once again,  Mike Myers did a great job playing many characters. I was glad to see Beyonce in this movie! She made the movie great! There are so many twists and surprises in this movie! I could not stop laughing at the stupid scenes in this movie!

Anticipation 1
Conflict 1
Engagement 0
Entertainment 2
Production 1
Total 5

Maybe it's not that good as first two parts but it's still very funny. Some jokes were already used in previous parts, but it was made a little differently, so it still was very funny. There were also some new jokes, in the opening we see Tom Cruise playing Austin, that was kinda funny. As in previous films there was some Dr. Evil and Scott Evil father-son relationship scenes, maybe it wasn't that good as in previous films (like when Dr. Evil and Scott were at Jerry Springer's show in The Spy Who Shagged Me), but still some moments were really funny. This film spoofs not only James Bond movies, but some other movies too, like The Silence of the Lambs or Godzilla.

I can't say that this movie was terrible, but it is definitely not as good as the previous one and definitely not as good as the original.  One of the biggest problems is the Mike Meyers plays too many characters, and his ability to play any of the characters has gone down drastically.There were some genuinely good moments in the movie, but there were also some that made me squirm at having to watch them.  Squirmy scenes included the jokes that were easy to see coming, the jokes that just fell flat, the bodily substance jokes (just plain gross), and the stupid cameos.  The cameos would have been funny maybe as a MTV movie awards skit, but not as a part of the movie.Overall I gave it a 5/10.

Third in the Trilogy of Austin Powers films created by Mike Myers,"Goldmember" has Star Power and fine performances, but fails when it runs out of ideas . The opening sequence comes out swinging.It is one of the most creative and inventive uses of the medium. As a matter of fact the first half of the film is very good, unfortunately, it fails to maintain the same creative energy, when Myers goes back to using bodily fluid jokes ad infinitum.The character of "Goldmember"(Mike Myers),threatens the world with demolition, if his demands are not met.Austin Powers teams up with his father Niles Powers(Michael Caine)and Foxy Cleopatra(Beyonce' Knowles), Austin's current Love interest, to defeat Goldmember, Dr. Evil and the rest of the Clan.Their adventures take them thru time to the swinging 60's and back to the present, with a major twist in Dr. Evil's lair near the end !Michael Caine has great comic timing, when he has material to work with, he should have been given more. Beyonce' steals her scenes with terrific moves and talent that just radiates from the screen . Verne Troiyer is wonderful as the vertically challenged Mini-Me. Watch for the transformation of Seth Green into a Ron Howard lookalike.Unfortunately, with all of the Star Power, the script lags the talent, and you have too many people , standing around as filler. All in all, a fun time, if you can forgive the script and Myers for not providing more for the film !

Review title: Better than SPY WHO SHAGGED ME!
Review_body: I really enjoyed this Austin Powers flick, as I have enjoyed them all. The opening scene in GOLDMEMBER was hilarious!!! I loved it, and there are a lot of big stars in this film that weren't known to be in it, via trailers, or interviews. But it is great. Worth seeing a few times.

Review title: Mike Myers has run this one into the ground.
Review_body: Let me say that I really enjoyed the first two Austin Powers movies, I own both of them. They were fresh and very funny stories. Myers was just incredible, one of the truly great comedic performances of all time. However, this third installment is just plain terrible! Can you say "milk it"? Well here they have milked it bone-dry. I cannot begin to describe all of the problems with this pathetic film, but here are a few. There is no story, or at least not much of one. Too many worthless cameos. Speilberg and Cruise don't make this movie funny by just being there. Brittany Speers is only funny when she tries to be serious. Paltrow has a cameo for no reason at all. Worthless additions to the cast. Michael Caine and Foxy Cleopatra do not do anything approaching comedy during the whole film. Moreover, the movie barely features at all the supporting characters of Dr. Evil's gang from the first two movies. Those were the people that made this series a hit. There is nothing that was good about the first two films in this one. This film looks like a rushed, slapped together, piece of garbage. There is no heart or brain. Many parts of the movie were very flat and looked rather stupid. Often, the film has to resort to crude sexual anatomy jokes for cheap laughs. I did laugh at some parts of this film. Myers is one of the most gifted comedians ever, you have to laugh at some stuff. Moreover, I thought his Goldmember character was funny and not used enough. But overall, this movie plays like a bad series of SNL skits. There is a part in the film were Ozzy (yet another worthless cameo) complains that this movie is just rehashed and reused jokes. You know what, he was right! * out of ****. Put it to rest, Mike.

Review title: Austin Should Have Stopped At One
Review_body: I really enjoyed the first Austin Powers (Mike Myers) movie, Austin Powers: International Man of Mystery. It was fresh, even though it was a retread of the James Bond movies, but more importantly it was funny. It was funny because a 60s swinger was in the politically correct 90s and have a very hard time fitting in. The second movie, Spy Who Shagged Me, was not as good as the first, mainly because it takes Powers back to the 60s, losing it's primary source of humor. Now, we have this train wreck of a movie, Austin Powers in Goldmember, a movie that looks like a boat who has lost it's rudder. The only interesting character in the movie is Austin Powers' father, played by Michael Caine, but is sorely underused. The Powers' babe of this movie is Beyonce, playing Foxxy Cleopatra in a Pam Grier-esquire homage to the blaxploitation movies of the 70s, though I do not remember a skin-eating Dutch man running Studio 54 in New York, or what ever the movie was parodying in that scene. The movie almost looks like there are too many ideas crammed into the 94 minutes of running time. The highlight of the movie is the first 5 minutes, when there are surprise cameos playing familiar characters, but the joy and surprise is done early, and the movie goes downhill from there. I do not know why Myers thinks it's cute to have Dr. Evil do silly musical numbers, or why mole jokes are funny. So much is wasted by the last two Austin Powers movies that it's really a shame. Sure there are funny moments. My favorite was when Godzilla is crashing through Tokyo (don't ask, it's not that important), but the laughs are few and far between. If there is a forth Austin Powers movie, let's hope that they get back to the basics, Austin Powers trying to figure out where he is in life when living in the 1990s or early 2000s, still trying to figure out how Liberracce became gay.

Review title: Sometimes the comedy is inventive and sometimes its derivative
Review_body:
My Rating: **1/2 out of ****.The third film in a movie trilogy is most of the time the worst. Austin Powers in Goldmember definitely proves that point. This is not a bad movie but it clearly shows in areas that Mike Myers was running out of ideas.
The first two Austin Powers were enjoyable and fresh. Mike Myers clearly showed that he was talented. Goldmember is watchable but not always fresh. The viewer will clearly see that some jokes from the second film are reused here and they are not funny this time around. The behind the tent joke is there (when it looks like Austin is doing something nasty but really is not) and a boob satellite joke (Replacing the penis rocket from the second one) are not really funny here.Then again there is somethings inventive here. There is a clever bit when Austin is talking to the head of a Japanese corporation and the subtitles are cut off by an object to make it look like something dirty is being said. That was particularly funny. The beginning is certainly inventive and very cool and funny.Mike Myers gave 2 performances in the first Austin Powers(Austin and Dr. Evil) and 3 performances in the second (Austin, Dr. Evil, and Fat Bastard). Myers is trying to outdo himself here by giving 4 performances by adding a new character called Goldmember. Alot of people said he was really pushing it when he added Fat Bastard in the second film but I thought Fat Bastard offered his share of laughs. However, Goldmember is a mockery of Dutch people that seems more offensive and irritating than funny. Besides Goldmember, I mostly enjoyed watching Myers.Beyonce Knowles is the new girl alongside Austin. Knowles is not bad but she is not as good as Hurley and Graham were. Michael Caine is fine as Austins Dad but the surprise ending when he reveals a "shocker" is lame.Despite some derivative comedy and a lame ending, Goldmember is worth watching. I dont know about an Austin 4 though. This series seems to be running out of ideas.

Review title: Lots of Fun in spite of the vulgar, gross, toilet humor!
Review_body: I would have given this film a 10 if not for the very sophomoric, gross-out, so called humor. I'm not a fan of feces eating, urinating in another's mouth or multiple penis jokes. This film does have enough other goodies to make it worthwhile and a lot of fun. To fully appreciate this gem, I recommend viewing it on blu-ray DVD. You will get awesome sound and crisp, sharp and extremely colorful visuals. This is one of the most colorfully dazzling films ever. The songs and music score are fabulous, the sets are eye-poppingly flamboyant and excellent, the costumes sparkle and shine. Many of the jokes are hilarious, the story is clever and Mike Myers playing 4 different roles is amazing. The cast in this series has always been perfect and a lot of fun. The only drawback for me was way too much toilet humor. A little of that stuff goes a long way.

What were they thinking? How did all those people (Cruise, Paltrow, Spielberg etc.) let themselves get involved with this turkey? Let me say that I don't object to the use of "naughty" language but when that's all there is I find it annoying. And the gross-out jokes and scenes are unnecessary since it's easy enough to be grossed out just by reading the news.And what is the point of those musical numbers and those lengthy and unfunny plays on words? I have to admit that I didn't get to the end of one of the many showings on the TBS Network which appears to be uncensored if not uncut (no pun intended.) since I'd really lost interest some time before.I didn't really like the first Austin but it was, at least, watchable. This is not!

Review title: Utterly lacking in charm, wit or humour.
Review_body: While I certainly don't expect sophistication from Mike Myers the tiniest bit of wit or charm would have been appreciated.With endless pratfalls and jokes that I stopped laughing at when I was still in grade school this mess has to be one of the worst films I have ever seen.The Austin Powers franchise has definitely  been played out and deserves to be buried -- deep.There are innumerable cameos by good actors that really should have known better.It amazed me how a fat paycheck will allow actors to permit themselves to be humiliated beyond belief.One surprising bright spot was Beyoncé Knowles as Foxy Cleopatra bringing, at least, beauty and sly humour to an otherwise thankless part.There was a second bright spot -- when `The End' flashed on the screen.

Review title: Thankfully the End of Austin Powers
Review_body: Just as one would expect, the "Austin Powers" movies got lamer with each showing. The first was alright: it wasn't the best comedy in the world, but at least Dr. Evil was amusing to listen to. The second catapulted Mini-Me into the pop culture landscape for a time, but was a passable effort with not much that was funny. The last "Austin Powers" movie (so far) is the worst. Mike Myers really strains himself to make the characters work, with little success. The jokes and writing were dreadfully uninspired and lacking in any form of wit (except for the final scene with the fat guy; I won't ruin it, and that's why I awarded an extra star to "Goldmember."). Very boring. Michael Caine doesn't really do much as Austin's father; not an interesting character in the least. Austin is boring, and Dr. Evil and Mini-Me doing hip-hop in prison looks so trite and unoriginal that I wonder why people who write these movies make oodles of cash. The character of Goldmember sucked. His accent and quips were the stupidest things I've ever heard. You can probably create better comedy in your sleep, and it would be better than the character Myers has created.This movie also has the most blatant product placement I've ever seen. It's already bad enough that there are TV commercials for cars and chewing gum before the previews; why do we need advertising IN the movies. Yeah, the movie makers stand to make a fortune, but it really shows how utterly crass movies have become.Steven Spielburg, Gwenyth Paltrow, John Travolta and Britney Spears make cameos, showing how in love with itself and out-of-touch with reality Hollywood is. Let's hope that this film is the last we'll see of Austin Powers for some time.

Easily the lesser of the series, its probably about time Austin bottled his mojo and retired. Lame joke after lame joke masquerades as a storyline in this 3rd outing for the goofy James Bond wannabe. Myers plays no less than 4 characters here, but again - its Doctor Evil that steals the show.Worth watching only for the hilarious cameos at the beginning and the gorgeous Beyonce Knowles, who proves that she can actually act as well.All in all very average, but anyone under 16 will probably love it.

Review title: Not bad for a third version...
Review_body: There are a lot of people that are complaining about this movie. First of all, yes, this movie has some potty humor, but all of the films had it (But this has the most, by far..) but this BY FAR has the best Austin Powers opening and anyone that would give it away is pure evil, baby!  Besides, what do people want from an Austin Powers movie? A LIFE CHANGING EVENT?  If your expecting CITIZEN CANE or THE GODFATHER, I think you shouldn't even buy your ticket.. Anyways...I liked a lot about this movie. I thought Foxxy Cleopatra was a great character and Beyonce did a great job for her first film.  Michael Caine was great as Austin's Dad and just like the 2nd version, Verne Troyer stole the show. Its kind of sad in a way that they seem to be making fun of him, but keep in mind- The guy is the one whos laughing, with endorsements and stuff- he's a millionaire by now..Dr. Evil is great as usual, and I liked the new character of "Goldmember", who yes is very gross, but not half as bad as "Fat Bastard", who was so not funny in this movie.. Note to creators: If you're going to make a fourth version, feel free to write out this character- Unlike Dr. Evil and Austin- he's getting old, and has only been around for 2 versions..Anyways, I don't have that many complaints except I would have wished they would have explained what happened to Felicity Shagwell and I really would have wished "Mustaffa" would have made yet another comeback.With the great writing, I think they could make another version. Austin could go in the 80's and the new "Austin Girl" could be Britney Spears.. Just a thought..Thanks

When films series reach their third instalment, many bolts and nuts start to come lose . However this is not a case with Goldmember which shows us that Austin Powers still has his Mojo. The horny spy is back. He may of lost some of his freshness but there no doubt he still delivers. If anything gold member is possibly the best instalment in the series.Mike Myers is still great as Austin powers. Just like the last two, he does the usually stuff you come to expect that's including making you horny. Micheal Cane also makes an appearance as Austin's dad which to me, was brilliant. The gags are what you expect from Austin, as one or two gags are reused from previous films but despite this they are still hilarious . Basically, Goldmember is everything you expect. Dr evil, his evil henchman, Mini me, Fat bastard, scotty are all still major characters.Now when it came to beyonce being Foxy, Mr Powers sexy partner, i was on the fence. Beyonce to me, wasn't the best choice but then again, she just there so that Austin can still crack a rude joke now and then. The arrival of The Dutch was flat. seeing as he plays a big part in the film, he is easily forgettable compared to other characters. Even though the gags still make me laugh, they are easily associated with the gags from the previous two films as there only several of new, unique gags.Goldmember is another proud entry into the series which still shows that Austin is still groovy and has got plenty going for him.
